column4: argh, seriously so apparently X/fglrx wants stuff to be in usr/lib64 but everything is in usr/lib
symlinking doesn't fix it it seems
i tried reinstalling fglrx and xorg so far
aticonfig claims i don't have a compatible adapter
yesterday it worked fine and i can't figure out what has changed
on Ubuntu, you just need to install fglrx-updates and give up the possibility of installing a vanilla version.
if you don't want such dependence on Ubuntu packages and just run the latest, you should switch to a community distro, like Arch.
it is possible to get it to work, but Ubuntu switched to multi-arch which complicates things.
the fglrx distributions makes some assumptions which are not true in Ubuntu.
you can of course work around this by analyzing the package contents, but that requires some technical skill that you might not have or you might not care about.
does that help?
I could.
and what did you do then?
and what version of Ubuntu are your running?
if you read the documentation, you can see trouble shooting steps.
documentation found where?
in the documentation location.
which will lead you to /usr/share/doc/fglrx-updates/index.html
you should read the manual for the systems that you are using before asking a question.

well, it turns out installing glew actually was the culprit... to get fglrx to work i have to apparently use the (dirty) fix of symlinking lib64 to lib... but the install script of glew actually created a lib64 directory overwriting the symlink...
you didn't say anything about glew to me.
what is glew?
